subsection.name: What is JGGApi?
subsection.p: The JGGApi is a Java Gadu-Gadu protocol implementation. JGGApi uses that well-known design patterns that minimize learning curve. As a result developers can write Gadu-Gadu clients faster than before.

subsection.name: What is the JGGApi license?
subsection.p: We use GPL open source license, therefore if you want to write the Gadu-Gadu client it must have GPL license as well. To find out more about open-source licenses point your browser at: www.opensource.org/licenses/

subsection.name: Who develops JGGApi?
subsection.p: The project was founded by Marcin Naglik (mnaglik@gazeta.pl) in 2003.
In November 2004 Mateusz Szczap (mati@sz.home.pl) joined the project and helped with the development and documentation process.

subsection.name: What version of JVM (java virtual machine) can I use?
subsection.p: The project was developed using JDK 1.4.2 but there should be no problem running with with 1.2, 1.3 virtual machine. However it was not tested against these. If anyone could report whether or not the library is compatible with 1.2 and 1.3 JVM it would be appreciated.
Due to nested classes it is definately not possible to use it with an old 1.1 java virtual machine.

subsection.name: Who should use this library?
subsection.p: This library can be used by anyone who wishes to write any kind of application or module that will interact with Gadu-Gadu server and it's users.

For instance, client application can be written in SWT, Swing, or even an applet that can be displayed in web page. Writing a simple servlet as a web gateway to Gadu-Gadu is also possible. Also writing application as a command-line similiar to EKG should not be problematic.
It is also possible that this library could become part of some CRM or workflow system implemented as a module that would allow interaction between some corporate system and IM users.
What is more, it is possible to write some kind of bot that could chat with users, such as very famous Alice bot.

subsection.name: Is it legal to use this library?
subsection.p: It is not since the company who developed Gadu-Gadu (SMS Express) states on their web page that people can connect to their server only from the clients authorized by this company. However, there are many open-source Gadu-Gadu applications that use this proprietary protocol, some of them available in official linux distrubutions such as EKG.

subsection.name: Is JGGApi better then libgadu from EKG project?
subsection.p: Yes and no. Libgadu from EKG project is more tested since it has a huge open-source community feedback. The disadvantage of the libgadu is that it is written in c language and there are some porting issues. JGGApi is a library written in Java and will run on every computer that has JRE (Java Runtime Environment) installed.
In addition, the JGGApi is an object-oriented library and has a clear design. It should be relatively easy for a new developer to write a Gadu-Gadu application using this library.

subsection.name: I want to write a Gadu-Gadu midlet for my cell phone, can I use your library?
subsection.p: Yes, you could use it but the library is quite big (>100 KB) and has not been optimized for J2ME virtual machine. Also it was not tested so please feel free to provide information about whether or not you succeeded.

subsection.name: How can I contribute to this project?
subsection.p: If you are a Java developer that wants to write a Gadu-Gadu application you can help by submiting bug reports and patches fixing found issues.

Also, there is a TODO list that always has some issues on it. Please feel free to look at it if you want to help us. If you convince us that you are valuable to the project and that you have Java skills we will be happy to include you on the list of our developers.

You do not have to be a Java developer to contribute to this project or even a developer at all. Some aspects include writing documentation, maintaing this site and testing the current version of the JGGApi library.

subsection.name: Does JGGApi depend on any library?
subsection.p: Yes, it depends on commons-logging framework that is a ultra-thin bridge to the logging implementation.
If you want to find out more about commons-logging framework take a look at: http://jakarta.apache.org/commons/logging/

subsection.name: Where should I begin?
subsection.p: First of all, you have to grab a fresh release of JGGApi from here.
Second of all, please read our Getting Started.
Third of all, your can browse JGGApi's Java Docs and sources online.
Last but not least, start writing your application or module and get some hands on.
